awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Combining Theory and Observations to Constrain Global Ocean Deoxygenation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use a combination of ocean observations and modeling to understand why the dissolved oxygen concentration in the ocean changes on timescales of years to decades. As oceans absorb heat, its oxygen content is expected to decline which will affect marine ecosystems and oxygen-sensitive biochemical reactions. In turn, biochemical processes can affect the oxygen level.  Understanding why oceanic oxygen changes remains limited due to sparse data and the fact that it naturally fluctuates. Furthermore, state-of-the-art Earth System Models, used to develop future projections, struggle to skillfully simulate present-day oxygen distributions. Given model biases, there is a clear need to re-calibrate model-based projections based on informed interpretations of available observations. The intellectual merit of this study is to perform a series of computational simulations to quantify linkages between the patterns of climate variability, ocean heating, and oxygen content for different regions. In conjunction with a novel synthesis of available observational data, this modeling study will develop a more comprehensive model for evaluating oxygen variability and change, thereby reducing uncertainty in future projections under climate forcing scenarios. Broader impacts of this study includes education and outreach about decreasing ocean concentrations in the ocean and its disruptive impacts on ocean biogeochemical cycles and marine ecosystems. Two Ph.D. students and a postdoctoral scientist will be trained under the supervision of the PIs. 


Ocean deoxygenation is a direct consequence of ocean heat uptake; as ocean waters warm, dissolved oxygen (O2) concentrations decline, with profound influences on marine ecosystem and redox-sensitive biogeochemical cycling. Existing observations are characterized by significant interannual to decadal fluctuations. Natural variability challenges detection and attribution of human-driven trends; however, it can also be interrogated to provide mechanistic insight. State-of-the-art Earth System Models still struggle to skillfully simulate present-day O2 distributions but these models are useful because they invoke mechanistic representations of key processes. The objective of this project is to improve our understanding of the mechanisms behind interannual and decadal variability of O2 globally and regionally. Low- and high-latitude regions exhibit distinct patterns in dissolved oxygen and ocean heat content. In order to isolate the impact of physical and biological controls on O2 variability, a suite of numerical simulations will be conducted, including some with a global eddy-resolving configuration. Combining observational and model-based analyses will enable quantitative assessments about the relation between ocean heat uptake and deoxygenation, and linkages to climate variability and trends.

por.por_cntn:
The loss of dissolved O2 from the ocean has emerged as a dominant factor explaining ecosystem responses to due to anthropogenic climate change. It has also become clear that the impact of ‘deoxygenation’ is intimately connected – at an oceanographic and at organismal levels – to the ocean’s uptake of heat and the resulting pattern of warming.  The major mechanisms driving ocean deoxygenation have been identified as the rise of ocean heat content (OHC) and its effect on gas solubility and the production and consumption of O2 by the ecosystems themselves.  However, the relative contribution of these complex processes to both global and regional rates of O2 decline remain highly uncertain, and are key to refining future projections of this phenomenon

The overarching objective of this project was to characterize oxygen variability on interannual to decadal timescales and to improve our capacity to detect and interpret the deoxygenation signal and its relationship to the oceanic uptake of heat and the drawdown of surface nutrients in regions of deep-water formation. We tackled these questions in the course of this grant, while also contributing toward mechanistic models of its implications for marine life. 

To better understand the links between climate change and ocean O2, and the consequences for marine life, we used a combination of historical observational data and 3-D global circulation models (the Community Earth System Model, CESM, and the Regional Ocean Modeling System, ROMS) to investigate the relationships among nutrients, productivity and oxygen.  Here are the key findings of this research:

  • Historical O2 variability in the Pacific Ocean has been driven by distinct physical mechanisms in the tropics and mid-latititudes.  In the tropics, the O2 changes are well predicted by density, implying a strong role for multi-year undulations in the depth of water density layers, whereas in the mid-latitudes, the input of O2 from the atmospheric via physical transport (ventilation) appears to dominate the variability.
  • The fate of oxygenation in the tropical oceans is strongly dependent on the isopycnal and diapycnal mixing in ocean models, helping to explain the high degree of inter-model spread in future projections of the tropical OMZ. 
  • In the North Atlantic ocean, historical observations reveal pronounced interdecadal fluctuations in oxygen content of the upper 700m. In the first decades of observations, annually averaged oxygen increased, reaching a peak in the 1980’s before beginning a decline that has persisted since. Oxygen in the subpolar North Atlantic in an ocean model (CESM) exhibits a similar multidecadal pattern to that of the historical observations.
  • In both data and model simulations, the temporal variability of O2 in the thermocline (100-700m) of the North Atlantic is strongly correlated with heat content in those waters. The decline in nitrate per degree of surface temperature change can account for the additional O2 decline per degree of deep ocean warming, implying a transfer of nutrients (and CO2) from the surface ocean to deep water during warm years.
  • Nutrient budgets in the North Atlantic show that increased nutrient depletion during warm periods is driven by an early start of the phytoplankton growing season driven by faster phytoplankton growth rates at higher temperatures.  Our results highlight the key role of phytoplankton growth rates – and their temperature sensitivity – in influencing the global response of ocean O2 inventories to climate change.
  • We find a striking difference in the projected loss of species richness from warming and deoxygenation under two climate scenarios.  The ‘business-as-usual’ scenario (RCP8.5) results in a major mass extinction rivalling those in Earth’s history, while the strong mitigation scenario (RCP2.6) largely preserves biodiversity.
  • We find that aggressive and immediate reduction of greenhouse gases can slow the rate of O2 loss substantially, and this has the effect of preserving habitat for marine species, and avoiding the majority of the present risk of extinction. Our analysis of the response of biodiversity to O2 loss and warming imply that climate policy can still exert a decisive role in marine extinction risk.
